text: 68. Moreover, as to the circumstance that some codices of Matthew's Gospel contain the reading, "For the woman[fn-17-P1760_723498:292-nf] is not dead, but sleepeth," while Mark and Luke certify that she was a damsel of the age of twelve years, we may suppose that Matthew has followed the Hebrew mode of speech here. For in other passages of Scripture, as well as here, it is found that not only those who had already known a man, but all females in general, including untouched virgins, are called women.[fn-17-P1761_723881:293-nf] That is the case, for instance, where it is written of Eve, "He made it[fn-17-P1762_723970:294-nf] into a woman;"[fn-17-P1763_724002:295-nf] and again, in the book of Numbers, where the women[fn-17-P1764_724073:296-nf] who have not known a man by lying with him, that is to say, the virgins, are ordered to be saved from being put to death.[fn-17-P1765_724212:297-nf] Adopting the same phraseology, Paul, too, says of Christ Himself, that He was "made of a woman."[fn-17-P1766_724331:298-nf] And it is better, therefore, to understand the matter according to these analogies, than to suppose that this damsel of twelve years of age was already married, or had known a man.[fn-17-P1767_724532:299-nf]
title: Book II.
author: Augustine

text: 10. Doth this peradventure perplex you, that I said of a virgin, and Paul saith of a woman? Let not this perplex you; let us not stop here, for I am not speaking to persons without instruction. The Scripture saith both, both "of a virgin," and "of a woman." Where saith it, "of a virgin? Behold, a virgin shall conceive, and bear a Son."[fn-31-P3105_1365618:22-nf] And "of a woman," as you have just heard; here there is no contradiction. For the peculiarity of the Hebrew tongue gives[fn-31-P3106_1365758:23-nf] the name of "women" not to such as have lost their virgin estate, but to females generally. You have a plain passage in Genesis, when Eve herself was first made, "He made her a woman."[fn-31-P3107_1365971:24-nf] Scripture also in another place saith, that God ordered "the women" to be separated "which had not known man by lying with him."[fn-31-P3108_1366118:25-nf] This then ought now to be well established, and should not detain us, that so we may be able to explain, by the Lord's assistance, what will deservedly detain us.
title: Sermon II. [LII. Ben.]
author: Augustine

text: "To inflict vengeance from the Lord on Midian."[fn-95-P9554_2792664:41-nf] For this man (Balaam), when he speaks no longer in the Spirit of God, but contrary to God's law, by setting up a different law with regard to fornication,[fn-95-P9555_2792838:42-nf] is certainly not then to be counted as a prophet, but as a soothsayer. For he who did not keep to the commandment of God, received the just recompense of his own evil devices.[fn-95-P9556_2793033:43-nf]

text: "And[fn-96-P9667_2809683:93-nf] Balsam the son of Beor they slew with the sword."[fn-96-P9668_2809826:94-nf] For, speaking no longer by the Spirit of God, but setting up another law of fornication contrary to the law of God,[fn-96-P9669_2809961:95-nf] this man shall no longer be reckoned as a prophet, but as a soothsayer. For, as he did not continue in the commandment of God, he received the just reward of his evil devices.
